item.description:
** WAIT - WE HAVE ONE MORE SPOT LEFT **

turns out there were three people who were going to make their deposits. I spoke with the people down here and for a slightly elevated price in order to hire more help, we can open this up to 15. With these three we currently have a very healthy 14 people so we have one more available if someone by chance wants it.

"The" Trek"

]THE TOTAL COST: (approximately) $1700, Deposit = $1000
*Includes basically everything, from international flight to internal flight, hotels, meals, incidentals, and trek
*Based on 20 people. Price will go up $100 if we only have 10. Don't sweat it.
*At the time of posting, One way r/t airfare from Boston on Spirit for $521. See www.sidestep.com

Welcome what to what could be my last planned adventure to the Peruvian Andes

I've put the pieces in place for an exceptionally adventurous trek through the Peruvian Andes. The themeis to discover some of the most spectacular ruins in all of the Inca Empire. Choquiqueroa is considered the "other" Machu Picchu and was built by Pachacuti's son, Tupac Inca. (Pachacuti was responsible for MP) It is also the sight the Inca retreated to just before they escaped to their final resting place and true "lost city of the Incas," Vilcabamba.

You'll fly out of NYC on SATURDAY, APRIL 23d to LIMA. Arrive at night and spend the night with the group (this is standard fare for most foreign travelers). We take the early 5am flight out of Lima to Cuzco arriving early on Sunday the 24th. For two days you acclimate - we don't want altitude sickness. So much to do in Cuzco :) Then the 11 day trek returning to Cuzco on May 6th and fly home either on the 7th or 8th depending on your preference. Or stay like me :)

HERE ARE THE DETAILS

Altitude: 1500 – 4600 m/4921 – 15092 f
High-season: May - November
Duration: 11 days - 10 nights
Level of difficulty: Difficult
After the conquest by the Spanish, Manco Inca and his successors dominated the region of Vilcabamba. It included several centers and settlements built to honor the last dynasty of the Inca: Manco Inca, Sayre Tupac, Titu Cusi Yapanqui and Tupac Amaru I. According to customs and traditions of other pre-Incan cultures, a Neo Imperial state was created to preserve all knowledge in religion and astronomy.
Vilcabamba is located northwest of Cusco, in the province Convención, in the eastern mountain range of the Andes. It has a chain of snow-covered peaks and high forest mountains with constant climatologic changes. The region is bounded by two very deep canyons, the canyon of Apurímac on the left and Willcamayu on the right. Through both run very fast-flowing rivers which have carved and still carve one of the most beautiful and spectacular landscapes of our Andean region.
1st Day: Cusco – Cachora – Chiquisca
We will leave Cusco early in the morning at about 5:30 am. First we will head for the little village Cachora (2850m/9350f), a nice place surrounded by beautiful mountains and the majestic glacier Padreyoc (5571m/18278f). Here we will also meet our horsemen who will accompany us during the trip. After having passed the village Capuliyoc (2800m/9186f), we will continue descending to our camping site called Chiquisca (1930m/6332f).
Climate: warm
Hiking time: Approximately 6 hours
2nd Day: Chiquisca – Playa Rosalina – Marampata – Choquequirao
After breakfast, we will first descend to La Playa Rosalina (1550m/4921f) and then climb up to the village of Marampata (2850m/9350f). From here we will have a nice view of the archeological complex of Choquequirao (3033m/9951f). If we are lucky we will even see a condor fly at nightfall. Our camping site in Choquequirao is about 25 minutes from the ruins at 2950m/9678f.
Climate: both warm and cold
Hiking time: 7 hours
3rd Day: Choquequirao – Choquequirao pass – Pinchaunuyoc
At dawn, we will first head for the citadel of Choquequirao called “Cuna de Oro” - the ‘Cradle of Gold’ - and enjoy the quietness at this place. Beyond, we will explore this archaeological site, of which only 30 % is restored, in more detail: we will visit the section of the palaces, the liturgics fountains, the temple of the high priest, the section of the llamas and the Ushnu. Thereafter, we’ll take the pass of Choquequirao (3270m/10728f) and finally we’ll go downhill towards our camp site of Pinchaunuyoc (2450m/8038f). Climate: warm with mosquitoes
Hiking time: 3 hours
4th Day: Pinchaunuyoc - Río Silvestre – Maizal
After breakfast, we’ll explore the settlement of Pinchaunuyoc thereafter we will head down to the deepest point of the small canyon known as Río Silvestre (1900m/6234f). From there, we will begin the difficult ascent towards the tropical forest of Maizal (3000m/9843f). After four hours, we will arrive in the community of Maizal where we will spend the night. Maizal is a nice place to enjoy a spectacular view of mountains and glaciers, such as the Qori Wayrachina (5512m/18084f).
Climate: warm and cold with mosquitoes
Hiking time: 5 hours
5th Day: Maizal - Qoriwayrachina
A pathway will bring us to discover the settlement of Qoriwayrachina which is still protected by high mountains and impenetrable forests. Based camp site is Maizal. Hiking time 8 hours approximately
6th Day: Maizal – San Juan pass – Yanama
Our journey continues following the Inca trail. Due to erosions, the road is not in good conditions, so watch your steps carefully. First, we will ascend to the top of the San Juan pass (4170m/13681f). From here, we will have a beautiful view of the valleys, mountains and glaciers, from which some peak more than 5000m/16404f. Due to the ecosystem’s constant changes, the mountain range of Vilcabamba is without any doubt one of the most complex regions. Our camping place will be in the little village of Yanama (3530m/11581f).
Hiking time: 6 hours
Climate: cold
7th Day: Yanama – Yutupata – Lazuna pampa
In Yanama we will experience the Andean life, its traditions and costumes. Our trek continues up and down through tropical forests such as Urpipata, Yutupata (3300m/10827f) and Tucarhuay and leads to the cave of Quellccamachay. Our camping site is called Lazuna pampa (3800m/12467f).
Climate: cold; hiking time: 7 hours
8th Day: Lazuna pampa – Choquetacarpu pass – Huancacalle (Pillaupata village)
After breakfast, we will walk up for a while until we get to the Choquetacarpu pass (4600m/15092f). Here we will have a short break and explore the area of the Andean hills. If we are lucky we will also see a Condor flying. After our break, we will descend to the little village Pillaupata (3200m/10499f), where our camping-site is situated.
Climate: cold; hiking time: 8 hours
9th Day: Huancalle – Vitcos, Ñustahispana (Yurac Rumi) – Santa María – Santa Teresa
In the morning, we will visit the archaeological sites of Vitcos Rosaspata (3080m/10105f), Ñustahispana (Yurac Rumi) (3050m/10007f) and recent excavations. Thereafter, we’ll take our bus downstream to Santa Maria where we will take a break for instance to enjoy the exotic fruit. And finally we will continue towards Santa Teresa village where we will spend the night in tents or accommodation.
Climate: tempered and cold with mosquitoes; hiking time: 2 hours
Transport time: 04 hours
10th Day: Santa Teresa – Hydroelectric – Aguas Calientes (3400 – 3000m)
After our breakfast, our trail leads us to Aguas Calientes (2050m/6726f), where we will spend the night in a hotel.
Climate: warm with some insects
Hiking time: 6 hours
11th Day: Aguas Calientes – Machu Picchu - Cusco
We will leave our hostel after breakfast at 5:30 am and head for Machu picchu (2400m/7874f) by tourist bus. We will arrive at the citadel around 6:00 am. After a guided tour around the archeological site, including information about life and culture of the Incas, you will have enough time to enjoy Machu picchu and Wayna picchu (2750m/9022f) on your own. We will leave Aguas Calientes by train either at 2:55 pm or at 6:10 pm. Until then, you will have time to have lunch in one of the nice restaurants. Moreover, you can visit the hot springs in Aguas Calientes to relax a bit.
Hiking time: 02 hours

Included:
Transport:
Private transport from the hotel to Cachora
Transport from Huancacalle to Santa Teresa
Bus up and down to Machu Picchu
Tourist train from Aguas Calientes to Cusco or train from Aguas Calientes to Ollantaytambo and to Cusco by bus
Entrance fees to Choquequirao
Entrance fees to Vilcabamba
Entrance fees to Machu Picchu
Basic hotel in Santa Teresa
Hotel in Aguas Calientes
Meals during the excursion (breakfast, lunch, dinner and snacks)
Dinner in Aguas Calientes
Professional bilingual guide
High quality camping equipment (professional 2-persons tents, Doite, Model Kailas 3, extra light/4.5kgs and Doite, Model Himalaya, extra light/4.5kgs, both are for 2 persons. Mattresses, eating tent with table and chairs, bathroom tent)
Cook and cooking equipment
Horseman and mules, for our camping and personal equipment of customer
Emergency horse
First-aid kit, oxygen bottle and safety rope
Not included:
Sleeping bag (rentable)
remember, you can still sign up for the December Trip

DEPOSIT: $800: Earlier deposits get room preference. Also be aware of Airfare increases. Make though Paypal to keng223@gmail.com. If you pay via CC then add 2.9%, via bank account is free.

Machu Picchu Trek: http://www.meetup.com...
Vilcabamba Trek: http://www.meetup.com...
item.name: Peru - Vilcabamba, Choquequirao, Cota Coca and Corihuayra + Machu Picchu
